row.cell:
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
Le réseau de cable télégraphiques sous-marins de cette compagnie
constitue le moyen de communication le plus
direct et le plus rapide d'Egypte pour l'Europe, l'Amérique
du Nord et du Sud, L,Afrique orientale, méridionale
et occidentale, les Indes, l'Australie, la Nouvelle-Zélande, la
Chine et le Japon.
Pour assurer une transmission rapide, les télégrammes
doivent porter l'indication Viâ Eastern.
Voir le temps moyen de transmission le plus récent jusqu'à
Londres au belletin journalier publié dans ce journal.
STATIONS EN EGYPTE. Alexandrie, le Caire, Suez,
Port-Tewfik, Port-Said, Suakin. Bureau principal à Londres.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: The following steamers are expected to leave Port Said on or about the following dates:--
Port-Said to London via Brindisi
The BRINDISI steamer leaves PORT-SAID after arrival of Indian Mail. Combined steamer and sleeping car fare from PORT-SAID to LONDON via BRINDISI or via MARSEILLES £25.9.11
To the East.

The Mail Steamers leave SUEZ for ADEN and BOMBAY every Wednesday, and for AUSTRALIA and CHINA every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for CALCUTTA, fortnightly, and another for JAPAN. Passengers can embark at PORT-SAID.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. Thos, Cook & Son (Egypt) Ltd.… … … … … … … … CAIRO.
George Royle, Esq… … … … … … … … … … … … … … PORT-SAID.
Messrs. Haselden & Co. … … … … … … … … … … … … ALEXANDRIA.
F.G. DAVIDSON, Superintendant P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt. SUEZ. xx-xx-xx

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.
Fortnightly Service: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice-Trieste

(Departures from Suez) To Aden, Bombay, Colombo, Penang, Singapore, Hong-Kong, Shanghai, Yokohama, Kobé about July 5 and August 4. To Aden, Karachi, and Bombay accelerated service about August 18. To Aden, Karachi, Bombay, Colombo, Madras, Rangoon, and Calcutta about July 20.

div.head: BANK OF ATHENS, LIMITED.
div.p: BRANCHES: London 55-56 Bishops gate-street Within-Alexandria, Cairo, Constantinople, Smyrna, At Candia and throughout Greece.

The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece,
etc. Interest, on cash deposits: 3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0
per ann. for 6 months ; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months ; 5 0/0 per
ann. for 3 years and over. Savings Bank Branch receives de-
posits at 3 1/2 0/0 per ann., from P.T. 30 to P.T. 10,000. 23538-19-1.905

div.head: SUDAN DEVELOPMENT & EXPLORATION COMPANY, LIMITED
div.p: KHARTOUM: CAIRO Office, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil.

TRANSPORT DEPARTMENT. Six days White Nile Tourist Trip dep. Khartoum Tuesdays. Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT. Shipyard for construction of sternwheel steamers, barges, stream, motor launches, etc. Contractors for supply and erection of all classes of machinery, buildings, irrigation pumps, etc.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: By the 10.15 p.m. train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa a sleeping car is attached every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Restaurant Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Restaurant and Sleeping Cars on Luxor trains:
A Restaurant car and a sleeping car are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday and Sunday.

Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the International Sleeping Car Company in Cairo Station. 1st class Cairo-Luxor P.T. 200. Sleeping Car supplement P.T. 75.

MANUFACTURERS OF THE LARGEST AND MOST EFFICIENT Centrifugal Pumping Machinery In the world, suitable fcr all purposes, including RECLAMATION, DRAINAGE, IRRIGATION, SEWAGE WORKS, GRAVING & FLOATING DOCKS, MINES, & ALL MANUFACTURING PURPOSES.
These Pumps can be driven by Steam, Gas, Oil, Water, Electricity, or other power, for Lifts of from 1 ft. to 500ft., and from 5 to 500,000 Gallons a Minute. Makers of the Mex Pumps.
Results Guaranteed.
Over 50 Years' Practical Experience.
All kinds of Pumping and Irrigation Machinery specially designed to meet Egyptian requirements.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head:
WHERE TO WINTER IN EGYPT.
The Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Telephone No. 5 Helouan.
Tel. Address "Tewfik, Helouan."
If you seek Health, Rest, and Recreation, Do not Fail to Visit Helouan.
"The Tewfik is Helouan and Helouan is the Tewfik."
The Tewfik-Helouan,"should be known to all who purpose to visit Egypt. – Glasgow Herald.
The Tewfik-Helouan,"is surrounded by pure dessert air under the best possible conditions." – Lancet.
The Tewfik-Helouan,"enjoys an exceptional position." Egyptian Gazette.
The Tewfik-Helouan,"views from the windows absolutely charming – Egyptian Gazette.
Tel Address:
"Tewfik, Helouan."
Office in Cairo – Stephenson & Co.,(English Chermists), Opera Square, Telephone 82.
General Manager – C.Aquilina,
(late of Thos. Cook & Son).
Pension from 10/3 per day.

div.head: CAIRO MENA HOUSE HOTEL
div.p: FIRST CLASS FAMILY HOTEL.
MODERATE TERMS.

div.head: CAIRO-SAVOY HOTEL.
div.p: Is Now Open.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE HOTEL.
div.p: On the bank of the Nile, Formerly the Palace of the late Khedive Ismail. Transformed into a luxurious hotel.
SPLENDID PARK.
Renowned for its afternoon-teas on the West Balcony overlooking the Park. Excellend Tsigane Orchestra, Motor-car running to Shepheard's Hotel and vice-verse.

div.head:
PAGNON'S HOTELS,
LUXOR.
div.p: LUXOR HOTEL.–This old established hotel, accommodating 130 guests, is situated amid beautiful gardens with entrance on the river. Resident Doctor and Anglican Chaplain, Billiard Rooms, Bar, Electric Light, and all the conveniences of a first-class European Hotel. Tennis Court.
KARNAK HOTEL.–Under same management. Beautifully situated on river. Nice gardens. Guests taken on pension. Moderate terms. Excursions arranged to Thebes, Karnak, etc.

div.head: GRAND CONTINENTAL HOTEL
div.p: Open all the year. Unrivalled position in centre of Cairo, opposite Khedivial Opera House and Esbekieh Gardens. Magnificent Verandah, French Restaurant and Grill-room, Bars and Billiard Saloons open to non-residents. Supper after the theatre.
GEORGE NUNGOVICH HOTELS

div.head:
VIENNA
HOTEL BRISTOL.--I, KARNTNERRING.
div.p: The fashionable residence of the elite of European and American society, situated in the most central and convenietn part of the City. Private suites of apartments, including drawing, bed and bathroom. Concert during the Five o'clock Tea and during Dinner.
American Bar, Central Heating, Original Otis Lift, Rooms from 5 Kronen upwards.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: An English Daily News sper, Established in 180.
Editor & Hanger: B. SMALLDA. Pplo. Ono astro Tarık. WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 28, 1904.

div.head: NEW JUDICIAL REFORMS.
div.p: The vernacular Press appears to be greatly disturbed at the new judicial reforms. Our Arabic contemporaries have expressed themselves as strongly opposed to the new scheme of holding Assize Courts whereby they allege that, both as regards the constitution of the Court and the procedural justice is not likely to be impartially administered. It is assumed that the Courts are to be everally constituted of three Counsellors of the Court of Appeal, but with power to the Ministry of Justice to replace one of them by Judge of First Instance. But, of course, ring to the absurd and ostrich-like policy of never taking the publicinto confidence until the Ro icon has been crossed, it is impossible to say whether this surmise is correct. However, assuming that the vox populi is on this occasion accurate, the native | Press appears to have ome reason on its side. The main ground of complaint is that the Judges of First Instance are removable at the will and pleasure of the Ministry of Justice, and that they will therefore think of the permanency of their posts, rather than of the rights of the accused persons who are brought before them. Such con iderations might possibly operate on the minds Of the Judges of First Instance, having regard to the unceremonious way in which their tenure of office has sometimes been treated, and also to the criticisms to which their judgments are abjected by the Judicial Adviser in his Rep its as well as by the "Comité de Surveillance." The other matter which is exercising na ve opinion, as expressed by their newspapers, the revocation of the power of appeal, which abrogates the rights and privileges hitherto enjoyed by persons accused of crime in this country. Upon this point we must admit that a reactionary tendency is observable, seeing that in all other countries the power of appeal is being considerably widened. We cannot of course foreshadow with any degree of certainty what will be the exact methods of procedure, but one thing we most earnestly hope, and that is that no discretionary powers, as regards appeal, will be conferred on the judges, for, one of the wisést who er graced the English Bench in the last century held it as his opinion that the co ferment of such a power placed the judge in most invidious position, for no judge would ser. be likely to grant an appeal when he think that he is right, and he is generally wrong when he thinks himself most right. The native Press asserts that the Legislative Council as a body is dead against the new proposals, but we are afraid that if such be the case, that consideration is hardly likely to carry very great' weight.

div.p: SMYRNA TURKEY-CARPETS.
Made entirely of wool and vegetable colours
THE BEST CARPETS IN THE WORLD.

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, December 27. The Tsar has issued a decree declaring that, in conjunction with the undeviating maintenance and immutability of the fundamental laws of the Empire, it is the duty of the Government to meet any change in the needs of the 1 people when the time is ripe for the same, even though it involves essential innovations in 1 legislation.

His Majesty directs his Ministers to consider the possibility of introducing various administrative reforms and to report to him as early as possible. The reforms are not to involve any practical change in the system of government.

The proposals include the bringing of the peasant laws into conformity with general legislation, measures for ensuring the application of the law for all alike, the establishing of legal responsibility for arbitrary acts, ensuring independence of the Courts, extension of the powers held by local institutions and measures to make them more representative, the revisiga of exceptional laws against enemies of public order, the introduction of which involved a grave extension of the powers held by the administrative authorities, the revision of religious restrictions, the revision of the disabilities attaching to watives in certain territories, and the revision of the Press laws in order to enable the Press to wortbily fulfil its mission of interpreting reasonable strivings for Russia's advantage.
(Reuter.)

ST. PETERSBURG, December 27. A rescript of the Tsar announces that he is having reforms studied with a view to giving the peasantry the position of truly free men. Other reforms include the participation of elected bodies in the administration of public affairs, the bettering of the condition of the working classes, the abrogation of the restrictive Press regime, and religious toleration.
(Havus.)

div.head: : RUSSIAN PRESS OPINION.
div.p: St. PETERSBURG, December 27. The newspapers protess an almost unqualified satisfaction with the decree, which the Noroya Vremya describes as the second enfranchisement for the pelaut.
(Reuter.)

div.head: GOVERNMENT AND THE ZEMSTVOS.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, December 27. A Government communiqué declares that the reform movement initiated by the Zemstvos is alien to the Russian people, who remain true to the old State organisation hallowed by centuries. The Government must oppose any anti Government meeting, State servants being specially held responsible for any contraventions of the law in this respect. The communiqué also calls upon the Press to assist in calming society.
(Reuter.)

div.head: THE BALTIC FLEET.
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, December 27 The Rus, in an outspoken article, say, that the time has passed for silence. The state of the Navy renders the task imposed on Admiral Rodjestvensky a superhuman one. The vessels destined for his reinforcement, now at Cron stadt and Libau, are dangerously defective.
(Reuter.)
The Hague, December 27. The rumours that Holland would place Sabang Bay at the disposal of the Baltic Fleet are devoid of foundation.
(Reuter.

div.head: SEIZURE OF RUSSIAN AMMUNITION
div.p: PEKING, December 27. Russia has demanded the restitution of the ammunition, mentioned on the 24th inst., on the ground that it was intended for the Legation guard.
(Reuter.)

div.head: WINDSOR HOTEL
div.p: Largest 1st class and most comfortable Hotel in Alexandria. Facing the sea, Central position. Under English management B1.110

div.head: CARLTON HOTEL
div.p: Bulkeley, Ramleh.
Ten minutes from Alexandria. First-Class in every respect. Very moderate charges. Bulkeley is the fashionable English quarter. Visitors from Cairo alight at Sidi Gaber Station.
G. AQUILINA, Proprieter.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: THE BRINDISI MAIL will be distributed at the G. P. OAlexandria, sat 7.45 a.m. tomorrow. -
THE NUBIA (SUDAN DEVELOPMENT Company's offices in London have been removed to 2. Broad-street-place.
TZIGANE BAND. - As from to-morrow, the Tzigane Band will perform every Thursday in Shepheard's grill-room from 1 to 2.30 p.m.
THE KHEDIVIAL YACHT "Mahroussa '' is leaving the inner for the outer harbour to-day t, preparatory to sailing for England on Monday and-next.
- HOLY CARPET.-The ceremony of the transport of the Holy Carpet to the Mosque of El n Hussein, Cairo, will take place on Saturday in next at 9.30 a.m.
A SMALL Dance will be given at Shepheard's Hotel on New Year's Eve. Holders of permanent invitation cards to the Monday to small dances are cordially invited.
New EGYPTIAN COMPANY.—The Committee le of the London Stock Exchange has admitted all the shares of this company to be quoted in the official list. The £1 shares were dealt in at about $2.
TRIPLETS.-The wife of a gardener, in the es service of Muhamed Pasha Mohsen at Bacos,
gave birth to triplets just before Christmas Day. One of the three has succumbed, but the mother and the two surviving infants are doing well.
es New DOCTORS, ETC.- The Director-General id of the Sanitary Service has authorised Dr. le Selim Nammour to practise as a physician in of Egypt, Messrs. Kevork Tchavonchyan, Emile
Nicastro and Missak Agob to practise as pharmacists, and Mrs. Rose Constance Tindale and Bertha Hubert as midwives.
THE "NOUVELLE REVUE D'EGYPTE" will, as to from January 1 next, appear as the Revue sed Egypte et d'Orient under the joint editor
ship of our excellent confrères, Messrs. F. Draun and George Vayssié. The publication will appear on the 15tu of each month.

CAMPING OUT AT CAIRO.--An English lady, who is coming out to Cairo, has made arrangements with one or two friends to live in tents outside the city. The necessary permission has been granted to the camping party, who expect to have a very enjoyable time in this improvisuu hotel.

MAN HACKED TO PIECES. - From Kotour, near Tantah, cumes a most unpleasant story of an Arab who, finding a husband to stand in the way of a intrigue, tells upon him in his sleep and hacked him to pieces with an axe. The woman who prompted the crime at once denounced the murderer, who has confessed his guilt.

R. BERKS.-The quadrille party given by the warrant officers, staff sergeants, and sergeants of the 2nd Battalion R. Berks Regiment out Boxing Night was a great success. A large number of friends of the Berks were present and a very enjoyable evening was spent, daucmug being engaged in with the greatest animation ap tu a late hour..

ENTERTAINMENT.- Mr. Scott-Leslie, the well known runciter, gave a most amusing entertainment with Mr. D. Norton at the Hotel du N11, Cairo, last night. His stories were as well told as uver, while the 'Lesson from the Water Mill' and Albert Chevalier's two sketches made a great uit. Mr. Norton's playing was very much appreciated, especially West's Tarantella.'

"EviL COMMUNICATIONS” Ero.-The depraying example of the Alexandria municipal scandals of a short time ago, whereby it was made evident huw easy municipal officials can make money by illicit means, has evidently

influenced the most adjacent Municipality at round the coast. We regret to learn that numerous irregularities have been brought to ral light in the operations of the Municipality at els Beirut. A commission appointed to investigate in the matter will also examine the accounts of
all the commercial and industrial societies who have engaged to pay a fraction of their profits to the Municipality of the town.
ce CHRISTMAS DAY AT THE RUDOLPH HOME.et About 300 of the poor and destitute men,

women, and children of all nationalities and religions, without distinction, were regaled with a good Christmas meal, consisting of macaroni, soup, beef, bread, and oranges, |-all provided by the liberality of the good

friends who furnished the money for the | purpose. During the progress of the repast a visit was paid to the Home by Mr. S. Carver, who takes an active part in the work of this excellent institution. Mrs. Sidney Carver and friends collected P.T.693, and Canon Ward sent P.T.300, contributed by the congregations of All Saints' and St. Mark's Churches, to
wards the dinner. Mr. G. B. Alderson sent two turkeys as a Christmas gift to the Home.

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The P. & 0. 8. N. Company's Steam Yacht "VECTIS," 6,000 toe, will leave Alexardris at 2 p.m. on Friday, the 801b of December, for MÅB-EILLEB, taking First Saloon Passengers only, at the usual mais

div.head: THE ALEXANDRIA FIRE.
div.p: At the meeting of the assurance agents yesterday afternoon, Mr. Meclavitch was appointed as expert to examine the building on behalf of the companies interested. Mr. Mareschal was appointed by the owner of the Old Bourse Building to act with Mr. Meclavitch as assessor.

The assessors for the stock of cigarettes, tobacco, material, etc., in the cigarette manufactory are Mr. Protopapas, for Mr. Laureng, the manager, and Mr. Agopian, for the insurance companies interested.
The committee of inspection will consist of Messrs. Barker, Behrend, Hewat and Manley. Several millions of cigarettes have been destroyed
Mr. Allen Borman, of Messrs. Borman & Co., Alexandria, has been appointed assessor of the damages, so far as concerns the bar and stores of Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi.
The Journal du Caire published the following telephonic message yesterday :
“C'est là que le feu s'est déclaré, causé, assure-t-on, par un court-circuit électrique.

"Es quelques instants tout n'a été qu'un brasier et le sinistre n'a pas tardé à se propager à tout l'édifice et successivement aux bureaux de l'Egyptian Gazette, puis aux magasins Walker et Meimarachi.
"Tous les efforts des pompiers ont été impuissants et on a pu sauver fort peu de chose."

The statement as regards the offices of the Egyptian Gazette is erroneous. The conflagration, thanks to the efforts of the Alexandria Fire Brigade, was brought to a standstill at the partition wall between our printing works and' Messrs. Walker & Meimarachi's stores. But the flames came so near that at one time they managed to creep through an opening at the top of the wall. They were, however, at once extinguished. The only damage done in our premises was by the water, which did some harm to our bales of printing paper,

We are requested to state that Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi's branch at Alexandria can execute any orders as in the past. The temporary entrance is at the back of the premises. The greatest expedition will be used in order to re-establish the bar and the stores in their original state.
All the perishable goods at the stores will be sold by public auction to-morrow morning at 10 o'clock in the okella behind the stores.

div.head: KAFR AMMAR COLLISION.
div.p: We hear that the inquiry held by the Railway Administration into the recent railway accident at Kafr Ammar has not yet established who was responsible for the collision. The driver appears to have run past all the signals, which were against him, but happily put on the brake as soon as he saw the train in front of him. He was slightly injured in the collision. Besides the brake and luggage van, dining-car, and kitchen-car of the "train de luxe," four goods carriages, including a cattle truck belonging to the slow train, were badly damaged.

Six persons, as well as MM. Bassiglia and Disertis, were injured, though much less severely. M. Bassiglia, whose condition was reported to be very serious, is progressing as favorably as can be expected.
A new dining-car has arrived just in time to replace that destroyed in the accident.

div.head: BUBONIC PLAGUE.
div.p: Yesterday's bulletin records two cases (one fatal) and a death at Suez, one case at Port Said, and one recovery at Toukh.

div.head: SUICIDES.
div.p: Mr. Bensilum, & British subject lately attached to the Wakfs Administration as engineer, has disappeared after leaving a few | lines scrawled in pencil addressed to his mother, whose pardon he implored for the suicide he meditated. No trace of the unfortunate young man has been discovered.
One Tadrôs Ibrahim as shot himself in al native hotel at Assiout. The reasons for the act are unknown.

div.head: ENGLISH FURNITURE IN EGYPT.
div.p: The fame of Maple & Co., the largest furnishing establishment in the world, is firmly established here. Our local furniture manufacturers can of course turn out some fair samples of furniture, but they all lack that taste and distinction which are the essential cachet of the workmanship of the great Tottenham Court-road firm. Moreover, Maple's prices compare most favorably with those of local furniture manufacturers, and when the superiority of the workmanship is taken into consideration the real economy of buying furniture direct trom England is apparent. With the facilities for river transport to Cairo and the South. there is very little trouble attached. Messrs. Maple and Co. have arranged for Mr. Oliver, one of their leading representatives, who visited Egypt last year, to be in this country again from the first week in January (the exact date will be duly announced by us). His address will be "Shepheard's Hotel, Cairo," where all letters making appointments should be directed. He will have with him photographs and sketches of all the latest productions in English-made furniture of the best class, together with a good selection of patterns of English-made carpets, brocades,and furniture coverings, and will be happy to give expert advice on all matters in connection with modern furnishing and decoration.

div.head: Anglo-American Nile Steamer & Hotel Company
div.p: River Transport of Goods Between Alexandria & Cairo
Three Sailings a-Week.

Alexandria Bonded Warehouse Co. Ld

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: H. H. the Khedive has been most graciously pleased to confer the 3rd Class Osmanieh on El Miralai H. V. Ravenscroft Bey, Station Commandant, Khartoum.
The following transfers and appointments have been approved :
El Miralai P. R. Phipps Bey, Private Secretary to H. E. the Sirdar, to be Station Commandant, Khartoum.
El Kaimakam L. 0. Fitz M. Stack Bey, Assistant Military Secretary, to be Military Secretary, and Private Secretary to H. E. the Sirdar.
El Kaimakam C. E. C. G. Charlton Bey, Deputy Assistant Adjutant General and Assistant Private Secretary to H.E. the Sirdar, to be Assistant Military Secretary.
El Bimbashi E. J. F. Vaughan, Aide-deCamp to H. E. the Sirdar, to be Deputy Assistant Adjutant General and Assistant Private Secretary to H.E. the Sirdar.
El Bimbashi Hon. W. A. Trefusis, 13th Sudanese, to .be Aide-de-Camp to H. E. the Sirdar.

The undermentioned officers passed the preliminary Arabio examination held on the 1st November, 1904 :-El Bimbashi G.Dansey. Browning, Medical Corps ; El Bimbashi: J. H. M. Arden, 1st Battalion ; El Bimbasbi J. F. Murray, 4th Battalion; El Bimbashi C. Garvice, D.S.O., 13th Sudanese ; El Bimbashi W. H. Ferrar, 15th Sudanese ; El Bimbashi A. E. Fitzgerald, 12th Sudanese , El Bimbashi R. J. Collins, 15th Sudanese ; El Bimbashi G. W. G. Hughes, Medical Corps.

div.head: A KURSAAL FOR CAIRO.
div.p: Although the Cairó hotels do their utmost to cater for the amusement of their visitors and organise innumerable "small dances" and fêtes for their clients, yet the want of a Kursaal for the Capital during the season is becoming more and more felt. It is not improbable that a local syndicate may be formed to take up this scheme, but as yet negotiations are still in a very nebulous state. A Kursaal run on the lines of those establishments to be found at the principal fashionable resorts on the Continent would, if properly managed, be sure to pay.

div.head: SHEPHEARD'S.
div.p: The small dance given on Monday last at Shepheard's was attended with the usual success. Dancing was kept up till about 1.80 a.m., when several supper parties were given in the grill-room. Among others there we noticed Baron Alb. Alliotti, Mr. and Mrs. MacDonald, M. de la Courwanegz, Mr. and Mrs. Herbert, Mr. Robinson, Sir William and Lady Russell, Capt. Healey, Col. Sir H. H. Oldham, Mr. and Mrs. McLellan, Mr. de Smith, etc.

div.head: NOTES FROM THE SAVOY.
div.p: The Savoy is filling very rapidly, many of the old habitués having arrived this week. Among the latest arrivals are Col. and Mrs. Charles Bell, Miss Bell and Miss Stevenson, Col. and Mrs. Jago, Mme. Kate Simon and the Mlles. Simon, Paris, Baron Thomas de Maas and the Misses de Maas, Odessa, Dr. Fricher, Odessa, Mr. and Mrs. Chas. D. Vail, New York, the Misses Laura and Mabel Houghton, Sydney, Major-General Ralph Allen, C.B., Mr. Cyril E. Hart, Mr. G. H. L. Mackenzie. London, Mr. Nicolas de Tchitchatchoff, St. Petersburg, Mr. and Mrs. Reynolds, New York, Dr. and Mme. Aufschläger, Hamburg, Mr. C. Turner, Mr. W. H. Pathe, Mr. R. G. Colebrooke and Miss Colebrooke, Mr. V. de Costa Audrade, etc.
The restaurant is full every evening, the Bracale orchestra being one of the great draws. This evening the ladies' orchestra will play at the Savoy.
Next Saturday's dance promises to be very well attended and many dinner parties are already arranged for the evening.
Mr. D. P. MacGillivray entertained a large party of guests on Monday evening at the Savoy Restaurant.
The annual installation banquet of the Grecia Lodge will take place at the Savoy on Tuesday next.
Lady Clarke and a large party are expected at the Savoy among the arrivals by the "Orontes."
Mr. and Mrs. Ellerman, of Ellerman's Line, will be again at the Savoy this year, and are expected shortly.

div.head: THE GARRISON DIRECTORY.
div.p: There are some rather unaccountable mistakes in the recently published Garrison Directory which seem to show rather careless proofreading. In the list of Under Secretaries of State the names of Messrs. Webb and Perry are omitted, and, stranger still, we learn that the post of Adviser to the Ministry of Finance is filled by Sir William Garstin and Mr. Vincent Corbett. To use a stereotyped phrase, "we have received no official intimation of this important change." It is, of course, a mistake, but the world in general, while indulgent to those who misspell addresses, and capable even of pardoning those who deprive Browne of its "e" and commit equally grave offences against the integrity of surnames, is disposed to be exacting when the posts and titles of some of the most important officials in the country are in question.

div.head: CAIRO GRAND HAMMAM.
div.p: Near Shepheard's Continental Hotels.
Turkish Baths, Plain Baths, X Rays, Electric Light Baths.
Massage & Electro-Hydropathic Baths.
Medical Director, Dr. Professor Fornaric & Dr. M. Resi
xxxx-xxx-xxx

div.head: NOTES FROM KENEH.
div.p: Keneh, December The new system of ghaffar organise on which is being instituted by the Interior will, it is hoped, be successful in lessening the number of crimes and securing greater safety to the residents. Mr. A. W. Hazel, Interior Inspector, and Mohamed Ali Bey, the Keneb Sub-Mudir, are arranging for carrying out his work in the markaz of Keneh. Ghaffars are being chosen who can be depended on in time of need. The old ghafars have been mostly dismissed. There are two relays of watchmen, one for day work and the other for night. A day ghaffar is to be paid P.T. 60 in the villages and P.T. 75 in the towns. The night ghaffar is to have P.T. 90 in the villages and P.T. 100 in the bandars. The “Sheikh El-Gafar" in the villages will have from P.T. 150 up to P.T. 200, while that of the bandar will have P.T. 300,

There is also an employé called mulab of ghaffirs who is to be appointed from the pensioned employés. His principal duty is to make a night patrol with the ghaffirsthin a radius of 5,000 feddans. This man is not under the orders of the Omdeh, but reports to the Markaz directly. His pay is to be P.1500 & month.

A meeting was held in the Keneh Markaz this morning for the distribution of grants-in-aid to the fikis of kuttabs. The Mudir, the Inspector, the headmaster of the Government school, and many of the notables of the town were prosent. Before the grants were distributed, a chapter from the Koran was recited. The Inspektor of Kuttabs, Sheikh Abd-ul-ate Hallal, made a long! speech to the fikis, exhorting them to maintain order, organisation, and activity in their work, and comparing the great success of the kuttabs this year with that of last year, and explaining the cause of the happy results. The Mudir, Gamal Eddin Bey, also spoke.

div.head: LETTERS TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but who wish, in the spirit of fair play to all, to permit - within certain nombre limits-free discussion.

div.head: THE FINANCIAL ADVISER'S NOTE.
div.byline: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN. GAZETTE.
div.p: Sir, I was disagreeably surprised to read in the Gazette this afternoon & scarcely disguised reflection on the better classes of the Hellenic community of Alexandria, contained in the extracts you published from the Note of the Financial Adviser on the Budget for 1905. That high official states that hashish smuggling reflects unfairly, "especially on the numerous and respected Hellenic community of Alexandria.". In view of the very cordial relations, which have always existed between the Hellenic colony and the English, espeo y at Alexandria, I must stigmatise this reflection as unjustifiable and unwarranted Your newspaper is read by a great many Breeks throughout Egypt and has been characterised by its sympathetic attitude toward the community, 80 the publicity which the Judicial Adviser's strictures will obtain must be a cause of deep annoyance to many ireeks throughout this country. The insinuations are unfair and misleading in the extreme. For example, can Mr. Benachi or Mr. Sinadino be considered in any way responsible for hashish smuggling any more than can any of the respectable members of the British colony be held liable for drunkenness among British sailors or soldiers at Alexandria 1 The Financial Adviser states that the leaders of the Hellenic community at Alexandria "åre no less interested than the Egyptian authorities in pung an end to the present state of things." 1 is an incontestable assertion, but it would have been far better unsaid. The paragraph is he led "A Plain Hint," and you have justly conveyed the general impression which it must reste in every reader's mind by this title. I fail to see why the respectable members of the Hellenic community should be saddled with this disgraceful imputation by the Financial Adviser, any more than the respectable members of the French colonies here should be held responsible for the presence of Parisian demi-mondaines in Egypt. If Alexandria was as near to an English port as it is to the Piræus. I am gure that the British colony in Egypt would have as many "mauvais sujets' ' as we have, and it is only owing to the contiguity of Egypt to Greece and Southern Italy, that the Greek and Italian communities here have so many undesirable members among them. To hold an entire community responsible for the misdeeds of a few of its members is utterly unfair and it is most regrettable that the first Note, which the newly-appointed Financial Adviser has issued, should be characterised by suoh & sad error of judgment.
I am, etc.,
ANGLO-HELLENE. Alexandria, Dec. 26.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: FOOTBALL The big football match of the scholastici year at Cairo, Khedivial v. Tewfikieh Schools, comes off tomorrow at 3.30 p.m. on the Helmieh ground, near the Ministry of Public Instruction. Mrs. Sharman is dispensing tea to visitors on the occasion.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOOTAL.
div.p: Princess Henry of Battenberg will probably stay at Assouan for a couple of months this winter, staying till late in March.

Among the visitors staying as the Luxor Hotel we notice the names of Cod It Stidnfek, the Viscount and Viscountess de Courey, Baron and Baroness Profumo, the Bishop of Lucknow and Mrs. Clifford, Vicente de Porttaree, and Professor Sethe.
The Financial Adviser and Mr! - H.' N. Bowden-Smith left for Khartoum yesterday evening.
Dr. - Rücker-Jeniseh, German Diplomatic Agent and Consul-General at Caire is leaving for Berlin on Saturday next by to Austria Lloyd steamer for Alexandria

Sir William Whittall, President of the British Chamber of Commerce of Constantinople, is coming to Egypt next month. Bir William intends to spend some time at Helouan As he has been suffering from rheumatism lately,
The rank of Moutemaiz has been graciously conferred by H.H. the Khedive on Herz Bey, chief architect of the Wakfs Administration.
Mt. Wakeman Long, the well-known solicitor and advocate in the Court of Appeal of the Mixed Tribunals of Alexandria has been appointed a judge of the Native Court of 1st Instance at Tantah.
Mr. and Mrs. Hogg are leaving Cairo for a trip to Khartoum this evening. 1
Mr. and Mrs. Lang Anderson Jaft Alexandria yesterday morning by the 9 a.m. express for Cairo to pass Christmas week at Ghezireh Palace Hotel
Mr. D. G. - Longworth, former editor-proprietor of the Sphinx, has arrived in Cairo from the Continent.
Mr. H. C. Simpsón, late of the National Bank of Egypt at Alexandria, has entered upon his new and important duties as director of the branch of the National Baat Medinet el-Fayoum.
Mr. Arthur Fraser, late of the Egyptian Markets, Ltd., has entered the University of Aberdeen in order to prepare himself for the ministry

The latest arrivals at the Tewfik Palace Hotel, Hélouan, include the Earl of Crawford, Comte de Galarza, Dr. Crawford Watson, Mr. and Mrs. Hugo Hoffmann, Mrs. Siewright, Mr. and Mrs. Erskin, Mr. A. H. Lory, Captain and Mrs. Sieb, Major and Mi Adoopk, Mr. and Mrs. Sternberg.

div.head: BAND PERFORM NCE.
div.p: By kind permission of Lieut Colonel G. M. Mackenzie, commanding, and officers and Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the following programme at the-Terrace, Grand Continental Hotel, to-mo row afternoon from 4 to 6 o'clock Mareh-"Waldmere"-F. Lose Characteristic piece "Traumbil''-Von Blon. Musical Idylle - "The Forest nger's Court
[ship - Eilenberg Song—"The Everlasting Day" Bevan. Selection—"The Mikado”-Sullivan. Valse—"Fusionen"-Strauss, Gavotte-"Willkommen"-Klose. Selection-"BlueBell in Fairyland": Slaughter,
Regimental March. Khedivial Anthem.
God Save the King. R. WATSON RAMSEY, Bandmaster
